game_overview: Agricola is an agricultural development game set in 17th Century Central Europe. Players start with a farming couple living in a simple two-roomed hut. During 14 rounds of gameplay, families work to improve their quality of life by building up their home, improving their fields, and breeding animals. Each Family member may take exactly one action per round, and each action can only be taken by one person per round. Players must carefully plan when to grow their family, manage resources, and ensure everyone is fed. Victory is determined by establishing the best farmyard through fields, pastures, animals, improvements, and family size.
objective: At the end of 14 rounds, the winner is the player who has established the best farmyard with the highest number of victory points. Points are awarded for fields, pastures, fenced stables, Grain, Vegetables, Sheep, Wild boar, Cattle, house type, Family members, and played Occupation and Improvement cards. Points are lost for unused farmyard spaces and Begging cards.

components_overview.name: Farmyard boards
components_overview.description: Individual player farmyards with farmyard spaces
components_overview.detailed_description: 5 farmyards for the players with farmyard spaces as well as 1 example on the reverse side

components_overview.name: Game action boards
components_overview.detailed_description: 3 game boards for the game actions including one with an alternative reverse side for the Family game, as well as two examples

components_overview.name: Major Improvements board
components_overview.description: Board for Major Improvements with scoring summary on reverse
components_overview.detailed_description: 1 board for Major Improvements with a summary of scoring on the reverse side

components_overview.name: Occupation cards
components_overview.detailed_description: 169 yellow Occupation cards (66 cards for 1-5 players; 41 cards for 3-5 players; 62 cards for 4-5 players)

components_overview.name: Minor Improvement cards
components_overview.detailed_description: 139 orange Minor Improvement cards including 7 upgrades from Major or Minor Improvements

components_overview.name: Round cards
components_overview.description: Blue Round cards with possible actions for rounds 1 to 14
components_overview.detailed_description: 14 blue Round cards with possible actions for rounds 1 to 14

components_overview.name: Action cards
components_overview.description: Green Action cards with possible actions that depend on the number of players
components_overview.detailed_description: 16 green Action cards with possible actions that depend on the number of players

components_overview.name: Begging cards
components_overview.description: Grey Begging cards taken when unable to feed family
components_overview.detailed_description: 5 grey Begging cards. During the Feeding phase of the Harvest, whenever you cannot or choose not to produce enough Food to feed your family, you must take 1 Begging card for each missing Food.

components_overview.name: Summary cards
components_overview.description: Summary cards with game phases overview and scoring
components_overview.detailed_description: 5 Summary cards. One side gives an overview of the game phases; the other explains the scoring at the end of the game.

components_overview.name: Deck cards
components_overview.detailed_description: 2 Deck cards (1 Deck I, 1 Deck K)

components_overview.name: Family member discs
components_overview.detailed_description: 5 Family member discs in each of the five player colors (blue, green, red, natural wood and purple)

components_overview.name: Stables
components_overview.detailed_description: 4 Stables in each of the five player colors

components_overview.name: Fences
components_overview.detailed_description: 15 Fences in each of the five player colors

components_overview.name: Field/Stone house tiles
components_overview.description: Brown/grey tiles for Fields and Stone house rooms

components_overview.name: Wood/Clay hut tiles
components_overview.description: Brown/red tiles for Wooden hut and Clay hut rooms

components_overview.name: Multiplication markers
components_overview.description: Markers for multiplying animals, goods or Food
components_overview.detailed_description: 9 Multiplication markers (can apply to animals, goods or Food)

setup.description: Place the three game boards as shown in the illustration. For the first game, use the Family game rules with the alternative reverse side of the first game board.
Each player chooses a color and takes the playing pieces in that color, as well as one farmyard.
On each of the two building spaces on the farmyard, players first place a Wooden hut room tile and then one of their Family members in each of these rooms.
setup.short_description: Place starting hut and Family members

setup.description: The remaining playing pieces (additional Family members, fences and stables) remain in the bag or are placed to one side.
Sort the remaining house and hut tiles and the rest of the game components and place them beside the playing area.
Sort the blue Round cards according to the Stage of the game. Shuffle each small pile and place the piles on top of each other with Stage 6 at the bottom, finishing with Stage 1 on the top.

Take the corresponding set of green Action cards based on the number of players and place them face up on the spaces to the left of the first game board. In a 3-player game, there are 4 cards, in 4- and 5-player games there are 6 cards.
Shuffle the yellow Occupation cards (removing cards not used for the current player count). Each player is dealt a hand of 7 Occupation cards. The remaining cards are put to one side.
Shuffle the orange Minor Improvement cards. Each player is dealt a hand of 7 Minor Improvement cards. The remaining cards are put to one side.
Place the 10 red Major Improvement cards face up on the Major Improvements board.
Place the grey Begging cards face-up beside the playing area.
Each player takes a Summary card and places it in their playing area.
Players choose a starting player who receives the Starting player marker and 2 Food. The other players each receive 3 Food.
setup.short_description: Determine Starting player and distribute initial Food

gameplay.turn_structure: The game consists of 14 rounds divided into six stages. Each round follows the same pattern with four phases: (1) Start the round - draw a new Round card, (2) Replenish - place new goods and animals on Action spaces, (3) Work phase - players take turns placing one Family member at a time on unoccupied Action spaces and taking that action until all Family members have been placed, (4) Return home - remove Family members from game boards and return them to the farmyard. A Harvest occurs after rounds 4, 7, 9, 11, 13 and 14.

actions.name: Extend Wooden hut or renovate
actions.description: Players can extend their huts by Building rooms or renovate from Wooden hut to Clay hut to Stone house. New rooms must be orthogonally adjacent to existing rooms. Renovation requires 1 material per room plus 1 Reed. After certain Renovation actions, players may purchase an Improvement or Fence pastures.

steps.description: To extend, pay 5 of the same material as existing rooms plus 2 Reed per new room. Place room tiles orthogonally adjacent to existing rooms.
To renovate Wooden hut to Clay hut, pay 1 Clay per existing room plus 1 Reed. Turn tiles over to show Clay hut side.
To renovate Clay hut to Stone house, pay 1 Stone per existing room plus 1 Reed. Replace Clay hut tiles with Stone house tiles.
When choosing the Build Room(s) action space, may instead or in addition build up to 4 stables for 2 Wood each.

notes.description: Each Family member requires their own room (exception: Family growth even without room in your home action).
Players can only ever renovate a complete hut. Rooms may never be renovated one at a time. Double renovation from Wooden hut to Stone house in one turn is not allowed.

actions.name: Family growth
actions.description: Add a new Family member to the family. Requires an empty room in the home (except when using the Family growth even without room in your home action). The new Family member becomes available from the following round onwards.

steps.description: Select the after Family growth, also 1 Minor Improvement action. Must have more rooms than Family members. Add newborn offspring to Action space. May purchase a Minor Improvement after.
Select the Family growth even without room in your home action. May grow family regardless of number of rooms. Add newborn offspring to Action space.
In the Return home phase, place new Family member in its room (or sharing a room if no empty room available).

notes.description: Newborn offspring are not available for use in the round when produced - they must first grow up.
Families are limited to a maximum of 5 members. A player with 5 Family members may not choose the Family growth action.

actions.name: Plowing fields, Grain and Vegetables
actions.description: Players can Plow fields, take Grain or Vegetables, Sow fields, and Bake bread.

steps.description: Plow 1 field: Take a field tile and place it on an empty farmyard space. If you already have fields, the new field must be orthogonally adjacent to an existing field.
Take 1 Grain: Take one Grain marker and place it in personal supply.
Take 1 Vegetable: Take one Vegetable marker and place it in personal supply.

Sow: To Sow a field, take 1 Grain or Vegetable from personal supply and place it on an empty field. Add 2 more Grain or 1 more Vegetable from the general supply. A player may Sow multiple empty fields with one action.

Bake bread (when choosing Sow and/or Bake bread): Use a Baking Improvement to convert Grain to Food. Fireplace converts 1 Grain to 2 Food, Cooking Hearth to 3 Food. Stone Oven converts up to 2 Grain to 4 Food each, Clay Oven converts at most 1 Grain to 5 Food.

notes.description: Grain and Vegetables are harvested during the Harvest. During Harvest, remove 1 Grain or Vegetable token from each Sown field and place in personal supply.
If a field is emptied, it can be replanted using the Sow action - a Harvested field does not need to be re-Plowed.
Grain and Vegetables in personal supply may be converted to 1 Food at any time, or to more than 1 Food with appropriate Improvements.

actions.name: Raising animals
actions.description: Players can Fence pastures, Build stables, and take Sheep, Wild boar, and Cattle. Animals breed during Harvest.

steps.description: Each player may raise exactly one animal as a pet in their home, regardless of home's size and type. The pet does not take a room away from a Family member.

Fence pastures: Pay 1 Wood for each fence. Fences border pastures and are laid between farmyard spaces. All pastures must be orthogonally adjacent. Fences may only be built if they will create a fully enclosed pasture. Each player may build at most 15 fences.

Each pasture may only hold animals of one type. Up to 2 animals may live on each square of the pasture. Pastures occupying 1 farmyard square can hold 2 animals; 2 squares can hold 4 animals; 3 squares can hold 6 animals, etc.
Build stables: Build stables for 2 Wood each. May be placed on any farmyard space that does not already contain a room or field. Only 1 stable may be built in any farmyard space.
Placing a stable in a pasture doubles the capacity of the entire pasture. Each unfenced stable may hold exactly 1 animal.

notes.description: Players may rearrange their animals at any time, as long as the rules are followed. A player may release some or all of their animals at any time.
The edge of the farmyard board, stables, fields and rooms do not count as fences. Fences may not be demolished once built.
Animals that cannot be placed into the farmyard must be returned to the general supply or immediately transformed into Food using an Improvement with the appropriate symbol.

actions.name: Play Occupation card
actions.description: Play an Occupation card from hand by placing it face-up and reading it aloud. The first Occupation card a player plays is free; each additional Occupation costs 1 Food (or varies by Action space).

steps.description: Choose the 1 Occupation Action space. Pay the required Food (first is free, subsequent cost 1 Food unless on a different Action space).
Read the card aloud. The text on the Occupation applies to the player as soon as the card is played.

notes.description: Cards that are in a player's hand have no effect on the game.

actions.name: Purchase Improvement card
actions.description: Purchase a Major or Minor Improvement by paying its cost shown in the upper-right corner. Some require prerequisites shown in the top left corner.

steps.description: Choose the 1 Major or Minor Improvement Action space (or Renovation space, or as part of other actions). Choose to play either a Major or a Minor Improvement.
Pay the cost shown in the upper-right corner of the card. Some cards show a slash allowing choice between two payment options.
If the card has prerequisites (top left corner), must have the required goods, tiles or cards on the table.
Place the card face-up and read it aloud. For Major Improvements, take from the board. For Minor Improvements, play from hand.

notes.description: Some Minor Improvements are Traveling cards - after use, they are passed to the player on the left.

Some Minor Improvements are Upgrade cards - playing them requires returning an existing Improvement. Upgraded Major Improvements return to the board; upgraded Minor Improvements are removed from the game.

actions.name: Take resources or animals
actions.description: Take resources (Wood, Clay, Reed, Stone), Food, or animals from Action spaces with arrows. All items on the space are taken.

steps.description: Place a Family member on an unoccupied Action space that provides resources, Food, or animals (indicated by an arrow).
Take all tokens from that space and place resources and Food in personal supply. Animals must be placed directly into the farmyard or converted to Food using an Improvement.

notes.description: Goods and Food build up on Action spaces over several rounds if not taken - there is no upper limit.

actions.name: Starting player
actions.description: Take or retain the Starting player token. In Stage 2 onwards, may also play a Minor Improvement when taking this action.

steps.description: Place a Family member on the Starting player and/or Minor Improvement Action space.
Take or keep the Starting player token. The player will go first in the next round.
May play one Minor Improvement from hand (available from Stage 2 onwards).

notes.description: The Starting player marker only moves when a player chooses this action - it is not automatically passed.

end_game.trigger: The game ends after the Harvest at the end of the 14th round (Stage 6).
procedure: Complete the Harvest after round 14 (Field phase, Feeding the family, Breeding).
Calculate each player's Victory Points using the scoring overview.

final_scoring.description: Score -1/1/2/3/4 points for 0/1/2/3/4+ pastures (fenced areas, not individual pasture spaces).
Score -1/1/2/3/4 points for 0/1-3/4-5/6-7/8+ Grain (in fields and supply).
Score -1/1/2/3/4 points for 0/1/2/3/4+ Vegetables (in fields and supply).
Lose 1 point for each unused farmyard space (empty and unfenced spaces without rooms, fields, or stables).
Each fenced stable earns 1 point. Unfenced stables earn no points.
Each Clay hut room earns 1 point. Wooden hut rooms earn no points.
Each Stone house room earns 2 points.
Each Family member earns 3 points (maximum 5 members for 15 points).
Score the point value shown in the yellow circle on each played card. Some cards also provide Bonus points as described in their text.
Lose 3 points for each Begging card held at the end of the game.

winning_condition: The player with the most Victory Points is the winner. If there is a tie, the tied players share the victory.
